Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A universal carbon detector for liquid phase chemical detection of organic molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will research and develop a universal carbon detector for liquid chromatography using flame ionization detection. The commercialization of this innovation is a product that will allow scientists to measure compounds with greater ease and accuracy, and drastically simplify the number and types of detectors required in liquid chromatography. The broader impacts of this product include faster drug and product development, more accurate purity analysis, better environmental sampling and more efficient research in many market sectors where liquid chromatography is used. The proposed activity will result in a product that competes in the $500M UV detector market, offering universal carbon detection without the need for a chromophore and linear detector response.

The intellectual merit of this project is the development of a low-cost, universal detector that is capable of responding to nearly all organic molecules with high sensitivity and linearity. Previous attempts to utilize the flame ionization detector have failed because of the lack of technologies necessary for the complete vaporization of analytes and removal of organic solvents. We have identified an oxidation-reduction microreactor that converts all organic molecules to methane vapors. We anticipate the proposed detector will have a sensitivity on-par with flame ionization detectors in gas chromatography. The technology would bring unparalleled molecular quantification to a wide variety of industries including pharmaceuticals, biofuels, environmental testing, chemicals and foods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Activated Research Company (ARC) has created a novel analytical detection system that utilizes Flame Ionization Detection (FID) in high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with funds provided by the NSF Small Business Innovation Research Phase I grant. This novel detector is the latest in reaction chromatography products offered by ARC and is referred to as the Solvere™.

 

The Solvere is targeted for the quantification of a wide variety of pharmaceuticals, biopharmaceuticals and chemical byproducts in the pharmaceutical and chemical industries. The detector offers several benefits over existing technology including a large linear dynamic range and uniform carbon response, allowing for the detection of a broader set of compounds than other detectors available on the market with limited-to-no calibration. The Solvere will minimize sample preparation, reduce the need for multiple detector, and save analysts time and money in the laboratory addressing several pain points in the $1B liquid chromatography detector market. The prototype designed and manufactured by ARC can respond to nearly all non-volatile organic molecules with high sensitivity and linearity.

 

The commercialization of the Solvere is the focus of a proposed Phase II grant. The potential societal benefits of this commercialization include faster drug and product development, more accurate purity information, better environmental sampling and more efficient research in many sectors. We expect immense improvements in the speed and accuracy of LC analysis, thereby leading to better and safer products, and faster development times. Introducing the Solvere to the global scientific community will have great and lasting impacts; best described by a current HPLC user in the drug discovery market, “[ARC’s] technology would be completely disruptive, it would change the paradigm of how pharmaceutical analysis is performed.”
